awd_titl_txt: RII Track-2FEC: Genomic Ecology of Coastal Organisms (GECO)? A Systems-Based Research and Training Program in Genome-Phenome Relationships in the Wild
awd_abstract_narration:
Nontechnical Description
This Research and Infrastructure Improvement Track-2 Focused EPSCoR Collaborations (RII Track-2 FEC) award harnesses complementary research expertise at the Universities of New Hampshire and Maine for an integrated study of genomes to phenomes in natural systems. The project team will develop a research and training program in the Genomic Ecology of Coastal Organisms (GECO) to advance understanding of the genetic bases of organismal responses to natural environments. The program integrates genomic technologies with field-based ecological and observational data of six species of tidal marsh birds inhabiting a harsh environmental gradient in a coastal ecosystem. The research will reveal insights into the genetic basis of adaptation at a genome-wide level and the links between genotype, phenotype and environment in the context of resulting organismal performance and fitness. These are key questions in evolutionary biology today, which can only be pursued through studies like this one of wild populations in dynamic, natural environments. The project will thereby advance understanding of long-standing questions in evolutionary biology as well as provide novel insight into genetic elements and mechanisms that underlie organismal resilience and adaptive capacity. The latter are important for predicting organismal responses to rapidly changing environments. To facilitate societal benefit, conservation implications of this project will be transferred directly to resource managers and other stakeholders. The project provides extensive training and mentoring opportunities for the team aimed at producing professionals adept at systems-level thinking at all biological scales. Educational activities include the development of a new graduate training certificate in ecological genomics and at the undergraduate-level, the development of active-learning modules aimed at addressing known conceptual difficulties in genetics, ecology, and evolution. Additional outreach programs will provide high school students from underrepresented low-income groups and rural areas with learning experiences focused on ecological adaptation and coastal ecosystems. 


Technical Description
One of the largest gaps in our understanding of genome to phenome relationships is how these interactions are driven and constrained by environmental forces in free-living organisms. This collaborative project between the Universities of New Hampshire and Maine addresses this knowledge gap through a research and training program in the Genomic Ecology of Coastal Organisms (GECO), focused on advancing understanding of the genetic bases of organismal responses to natural environments. The systems-level approach of this program links genomic, transcriptomic, and phenotypic data to organismal performance and fitness, using six tidal marsh bird species undergoing parallel evolutionary processes in a dynamic coastal ecosystem. The research will advance understanding of long-standing questions in evolutionary biology about the genetic bases and genomic architecture of adaptation, the influence of phylogeny on parallel evolution, and the relative roles of phenotypic plasticity and genetic adaptation. It will also provide novel insight into genetic elements and mechanisms that underlie organismal resilience and adaptive capacity, as well as the extended effects of genome and phenome variation for ecological communities and ecosystems. The resulting insights are needed for predicting organismal responses to rapidly changing future environments, a critical and timely scientific goal with important societal benefits. Conservation implications of this research will be rapidly transferred to stakeholders from state, federal, and non-governmental organization with a focus on translating research into on-the-ground actions. The program provides training and mentoring for early career faculty, postdoctoral associates and numerous graduate and undergraduate students in ecological genomics. It creates a graduate certificate in Genome to Phenome Adaptation; active-learning, systems-level teaching modules for undergraduate genetics, ecology, and evolution courses; and STEM pedagogical training for post-docs and early career faculty. A Diversity Action Plan guides recruitment and retention of program members and STEM-based outreach programs will expose high school students from underrepresented low-income groups and rural areas to scientific tools and research.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project was a collaborative, multi-institutional and interdisciplinary research, education, and training program focused on the integrated study of genomes to phenomes in natural systems. The program harnessed expertise in genomics, bioinformatics, marine ecology, ornithology, and ecological-evolutionary dynamics across the Universities of New Hampshire and Maine to increase research capacity and address key educational and training challenges in the interdisciplinary field of ecological genomics. The overarching goal of our program was to advance genome to phenome understanding in an environmentally relevant context, using a study system in tidal marsh birds. Tidal marshes are natural laboratories for studying organismal adaptation to natural environments. The unique adaptations of tidal marsh birds to the harsh tidal marsh environment provided a case study for our research and training goals. We focused on six species of New World sparrow, with varying levels of specialization to tidal salt marsh.

 

Through intensive field ecological data collection and genomic analyses, across thousands of individuals, we investigated genomic underpinnings of tidal marsh adaptation, focused on hypothesized adaptive traits of bill morphology, plumage melanism, osmoregulation and nesting behaviors. We aimed to address five fundamental questions in ecological genomics about 1) association of genomic variation and tidal marsh adaptations; 2) genomic architecture of adaptation; 3) parallel evolution; 4) relative roles of adaptation and plasticity in gene expression and phenotype; 5) ecological feedbacks of genotype-phenotype relationships; and one undergraduate education objective to improve students’ comprehension of genome-phenome concepts in ecology and evolution contexts. 

 

This research furthered understanding of the genetic and evolutionary basis of salt marsh adaptation in passerines. We identified numerous candidate genes and strong support for parallel pathway evolution, rather than parallel gene evolution per se, as the primary basis for tidal-marsh adaptation. Across the six sparrow species, we found examples of salt marsh adaptation driven by lineage-specific mechanisms, some shared genes, and shared genetic pathways. With respect to the genomic architecture of adaptation, we found evidence that some genes influenced multiple focal traits within species. Additional research uncovered gains and losses in families of non-coding microRNAs and identified novel variants of these regulatory regions of the genome, shedding new insights into contemporary evolution of these species.

 

Several studies investigated aspects of performance of tidal marsh birds in salt marsh environments. Using a novel, thermal chamber for field data collection, we found that sparrow bills function as thermal radiators, and that species differed in heat dissipation and thermal efficiency. The most saltmarsh-specialized species had the most efficient thermoregulation, likely reflecting an evolutionary response to heat stress and freshwater scarcity. With respect to plumage adaptation, investigation of feather microbiomes revealed limited within-species variability in microorganism communities, moderate host species-specific patterns in microorganism diversity and composition, and identified several taxa with potential feather-degrading capabilities. Further evidence suggested that plumage bacteria are acquired from multiple sources and may be specifically adapted to vertebrate hosts. Associations between plumage melanism patterns and environmental variables related to thermoregulation suggested a potential function of this trait. Using fecal DNA analysis, we identified prominent prey items in the six sparrow species’ diets and found that diet composition and diversity varied among species, largely consistent with expectations based on levels of specialization to tidal salt marsh. Bill morphology and microhabitat differences appeared to be drivers of diet differences. Collectively, these findings increased understanding of the functional and performance roles of key tidal marsh adaptive traits, and in the bigger picture they advance understanding of linkages among genotypes, phenotypes, performance metrics and fitness, in the context of environmental variation. 

 

This project trained 4 PhD students, 3 Masters students, 2 postdoctoral researchers, 4 early career researchers, and 80 undergraduates and postbaccalaureates, including 12 with independent research projects. Recruitment of field research technicians broadened participation of under-represented groups. We developed and taught 5 interdisciplinary, cross-institutional courses for graduate students and one for undergraduates. Our project generated a large amount of genomic, phenotypic, performance, fitness and environmental data, which is archived in public databases, including high quality reference genomes for the six sparrow species, whole genome sequencing data from ~12000 individuals, feather microbiomes, diet metabarcoding data, and three genetic marker panels of ~300 amplicons each, including in candidate genes potentially underlying adaptation in our key trait focus areas, including bill, plumage, osmoregulation, and circadian genes. We completed 20 collaborative, scientific papers and gave 47 presentations to scientific and general public audiences, including to the Secretary of the Interior and Director of US Fish & Wildlife service; numerous additional papers and presentations are forth-coming. Mentorship of trainees was facilitated with Individual Development Plans and interdisciplinary and cross-jurisdictional research teams. We partnered with local, state and federal natural resource manager stakeholders, including the US Fish & Wildlife’s, Atlantic Coast Joint Venture, and our findings helped inform decision-making about tidal marsh bird population conservation and salt marsh restoration.
